Spongebob Squarepants Mash-Up (Minecraft, 2022) Pros Explorable interiors for most of the iconic locations. Some nice story elements. Fun NPCs. Really good builds. Working rides in Glove World. A really fun mini-game in the Krusty Krab. Working Boatmobiles. You can play Squidward’s clarinet and Mayonnaise is in fact a musical instrument. The Salty Spatoon thinks you’re not tough enough. Cons You can’t go into certain buildings until after completing a mission which can be frustrating to those hoping for pure exploration. Mr. Krabs’ House and Grandma’s House don’t have interiors. Two rides in Glove World don’t work. Heavy reliance on custom models. Some places can be confusing to get to. A Spongebob mash-up pack is something I’ve been waiting on for years upon years upon years, and it’s finally here. It has a total of forty skins, and I absolutely love the selection they gave us. Although it is unfortunate that, due to Minecraft’s skin template, we couldn’t have a size accurate Plankton. Most of the interiors are phenomenal, although there is a heavy reliance upon custom models that Spark Universe has made. Now custom models can be good in some instances. For example, the dinosaurs in Jurassic World, and the ships in Star Wars are both good places for custom models to be used. And there are good uses of custom models in this map, such as Spongebob’s Alarm Clock, his TV, the cash register in the Krusty Krab, and many others. But, when you use custom models unsparingly, and as the only way to decorate a room, then they become watered down and aren’t fun anymore. Also, the use of custom models makes some rooms feel empty and unfinished. Regardless, the custom models still help more than they hurt, and they all look great. 9/10

Transformers isn't just a movie - it's a seismic event that shatters the boundary between childhood fantasy and big-screen reality. Michael Bay's hyperkinetic vision ignites a nitro-fueled spectacle where every frame crackles with electric intensity. Shia LaBeouf's Sam Witwicky pinballs through the chaos with manic conviction, while Megan Fox smolders as Mikaela, elevating her role beyond mere eye candy to a capable heroine in her own right. But it's when metal meets metal that this film ascends to godhood each transformation a symphony of impossible engineering, every robot-on-robot throwdown an earthquake of celestial proportions. Peter Cullen's return as Optimus Prime isn't just voice acting, it's a religious experience his baritone rumble commanding goosebumps as it rallies both humans and Autobots alike. Hugo Weaving's menacing rasp as Megatron drips with palpable malevolence, the yin to Prime's yang in this heavy-metal opera. From Bumblebee's puppy-like charm to Starscream's treacherous snarl, every Transformer pulses with distinct personality. Bay's camera practically overheats trying to capture the sheer, overwhelming coolness erupting across the screen - sleek vehicle modes, city-leveling battles, and action set-pieces that redefine the very concept of 'epic'. Yet amidst this visual feast, the film's attempts at humor often fall flat, relying on cringe-worthy gags and juvenile jokes that clash with the epic tone. Despite this misstep, Transformers doesn't just raise the bar for blockbuster entertainment - it straps rockets to that bar and blasts it into the stratosphere, leaving audiences dazed, delirious, and craving more of its metal-morphing magic.

Michael bay's visually stunning and meditatively imaginative transformers is a heartwarming experience that shows a bold message of being a hero and learning your ways of dealing with your own issues as a kid and this movie was like the E T extra terrestrial of the 2000s bay was like trying to be the next Spielberg. And he succeeded well the acting is phenomenal Shia labeouf gives a very convincing performance as the high school kid that tries to solve his issues, has a crush on a girl and gets into a relationship with bumblebee which he gets as his new car and the chemistry between them is so heartwarming and it reminds me of the relationship with the kid and E T in spielberg's 1982 classic and another thing that really impresses me is how this has two storylines where it opens from a narration of Optimus prime aka leader of the autobots of how the autobots and decepticons got into a fight and then found the planet earth which the decepticons want to destroy buy getting the allspark and the autobots try to get to it first to defend it and how it later shows Sam witwicky's story of his life and his issues the two stories come togeather later on when Sam meets the rest of the autobots and not to mention the action scenes are so impressive that it's like what you havent seen in other action films before and as you can tell its the style of action that only Michael bay can film it's so astonishing and visually stunning bay is a mastermind at providing impressive visuals and camerawork his film is beautifullly shot and the final battle downtown was so fun to watch and like I said earlier it's well acted with great performances from the supporting cast such as John turturro who's charachter is very witty in this first movie and not to mention josh duhamel and tyrese Gibson as the millitary soldiers they were very likable and helpful to film I loved how they participated in the final battle and helping Shia labeouf in protecting the all spark cube, and let's not forget the great jon voight who gives a brilliant supporting performance as the defense secretary John Keller his charachter was very likeable and I liked how he gets everyone to that base near the Dam. The score from Steve jablonsky is terrific and very intriguing and is very comparable to the brilliant score of Hans Zimmer in Christopher Nolan's Batman trilogy. Bay am with the help of Spielberg and the cast and crew gave us a fun and memorable blockbuster hit that provides the best entertainment you get from the industry that's full of wit, charm, soul, and imagination the film made sense the story was really good and there was substance to it having charachters I cared for it. The first bay Transformers ( 2007) overall is a wonderful achievement and a powerful film with tremendous action and engaging storytelling of how the autobots and decepticons became enemies and showing the heartbreaking life of Shia labeouf's Sam witwicky, it's an impressive work of perfection and critics should be impressed with it and what bay has given us with it. This is in my opinion the E T of the 21st century and one of the best films of 2007 and of Michael bay's filmography. It's Too bad they had to make sequals to it that weren't good but unlike those this had heart, soul and meaningfulness to it along with having compelling charachters and an intriguing story this film gets a strong A-

Transformers is one of those movies that I will always be passionate talking about because of how much I watched this movie as a kid. I dressed up as Bumblebee and Optimus back to back as a kid and so I might have some bias when it comes to this movie. Shia as Sam is probably in my Top 5 favorite leading characters within a movie, his chemistry with Megan Fox in these movies was so charming and I remember wanting a high school relationship just like them. Also the idea of getting a car and it turns into an alien robot was just so cool and badass to me as a kid and it still is to me today. One thing I can appreciate more that I'm older is how much this movie focuses on the military and government aspect as this movie does have that feel of an army movie which I felt like those scenes were so amazingly written as you understand what is happening and feel the threat within the movie. It's just so crazy to me how the writers took a simple premise and elevated it, and not just that but then somehow Michael Bay's execution on the direction he took. This movie also does have some of the cheesiness that is in Michael Bay films that I enjoy from him. I think Rise of the Beasts tried to lose the cheesiness and tried to ground the story which I felt didn't work as the cheesiness that Bay brings is what I think is best for these films as this movie isn't goofy and it has a more serious approach than the new movies but still keeping that cheesy style with the high school scenes and the small jokes here and there and the iconic score that is muscle memory to me. Overall, Transformers is one of my favorite movies of all time as it is action-packed, has a great cast with Shia and Megan, the story itself is also written well with an awesome execution by Michael Bay, and sticks to a serious tone while having some cheesiness to it. Transformers is an A-.

Over 15 years old and this is one of Michael Bay’s most fun movies Everything you could imagine a summer popcorn flick is based on the 1980’s toy franchise/cartoon series Fans were of course worried about how Bay would adapt these action figures but he managed to make it entertaining as well as exciting for the kid in us all I remember seeing it with my sister Cara on July 4th Two alien races; the Autobots and Decepticons waged war on their planet Cybertron A cube called the All Spark was lost during the battle ending up on Earth Then we see that both alien races have hidden themselves as motor vehicles, helicopters etc. A young boy named Sam ends up with a yellow Camero called Bumblebee sending out a distress signal to call his Autobots allies led by Optimus Prime The Decepticons led by Megatron are after the All Spark to transform all human technology to take over the universe Sam and love interest, Michaela get stuck in the middle of the war along with soldiers and other government officials Sam and the humans will need to team up with the Autobots to save Earth and stop the Decepticons This was such a fun introduction to the franchise, my dad loved the opening sequence but felt the movie's length The animators did a fantastic job bringing the Autobots and the Decepticons to life, I was so afraid it wasn't gonna work Michael Bay still delivers the fun action and special effects yet the story is still very dumb next to the sex jokes and toilet humor and the blatant racism I was disappointed by all the human parts in the movie; dumb corny or downright annoying The story is ridiculous when you stop to think But Shia LaBeouf and Megan Fox did get their rises to fame and it was a big treat for fans for Peter Cullen to voice the original Optimus Prime from the 80s cartoon I love Steve Jablonsky's epic score and it made Linkin Park cool again It's a shame Shia faded into obscurity and Megan faced a lot of early 2000s misogyny but Hasbro still made a lot of money making toys and merchandise So glad they ended up making more movies introducing more Autobots and Decepticons as well as expanding the mythos

A beautiful sunset graces the country landscape. Shia LeBeouf and Megan Fox smack lips on the hood of a yellow camero as Optimus Prime gazes pensively into the sky. He sends a hopeful message to any surviving autobots scattered across the universe. The screen goes black and we're fed an audio feast of Linkin Parks "What I've Done." An awesome ending, to an awesome movie! Look, I get it. This is not an oscar movie. There are no deep dives into the human condition, no erudite discussions on the meaning of existence, or what it means to truly love. This film knows what it is: giant alien robots fighting! And damn, does it deliver! Transformers comes from far distant past of 2007, when special effects really started getting good, and it impressively holds up. In fact, it looks far better than your average Marvel project from the last 5 years, though I can't ascertain as to why that would be the case. Maybe modern special effects artists are overworked, underpaid, or just getting lazy. Regardless, throughout two and half hour runtime, which breezed by, I found myself continuously asking how they made everything look so real. It's an unsung triumph in movie visual effects. Sam (Shia LaBeouf) buys his first car which turns out to be an alien robot named bumblebee from a wartorn world called Cybertron (I guess they have bumblebees on Cybertron, otherwise where did his name come from?). Him and Mikaela (Megan Fox), his highschool crush, embark on an adventure to help Bumblebee and the other Autobots find the Allspark, a magic cube that brings machines to life. They must find it before the Decepticons do, or the whole universe is doomed, I guess. The decepticons are led by Megatron, voiced by Hugo Weaving, who I guess needed a quick paycheck. I'm not sure why Micheal Bay felt the need to bring in a top-notch actor to say a few goofy lines into a microphone which would then be enhanced and distorted to the point where Weaving's voice would be unrecognizable. To each their own. This movie's strength lies in it's ability to make giant robots turn into various vehicles, and to do it plausibly. These are not lame automatons that fold their arms in, crouch down and suddenly become a car. When they transform, the camera is often moving thematically around their bodies so you get an up-close, personal experience. You can literally see each individual part, and there's thousands of them, moving to its correct location as the truck slowly turns into a thirty foot tall man. This action happens in the blink of an eye in some cases where the decepticon will jump ten feet into the air, transform into an attack helicopter and fly away, all without missing a beat or screwing with the physics needed to make it believable. The writing is on the level of a Saturday morning cartoon. Optimus Prime speaks boldly through motivational bumper stickers as he ask Sam if he will help them. Why they would want the help of a panicky teenage boy is beyond me. I know they need to get the glasses from him, but why don't they get the glasses, and tell Sam to kindly screw off since THEY HAVE A WAR TO FIGHT? The autobots are even nice enough to conceal themselves so that Sams parents don't see them while he searches for the glasses in his room. As if these highly advanced beings who are trying to save the universe would worry about remaining a secret from this random kids parents. Although, it does set up one the most hilarious scenes in the movie as they "hide" in Sams backyard. This movie is a master-class in visual effects and action sequences! One of the best I have yet to see to this day! It's a fun, loud, colorful romp with a lot of humor even a little bit of heart thrown in. A must see for action, and sci-fi fans!

PROS: -Outstanding VFX for 2007 standards, even the fact that it still looks awesome today, even looks in broad daylight and very realistic! -Awesome action scenes, both regarding humans and Autobots fighting the Decepticons, with some of my favorites are Prime vs Bonecrusher, Starscream destroying jets, and Prime vs Megatron. -Solid story, probably the most cohesive one considering the rest of the films get more messy. -Solid humor, some I actually enjoyed and find memorable. -Great human characters, for the most part they're actually good compared to other movies I've seen. -Transformer characters are awesome! CONS: -Humor can be hit or miss to some. -Some of the parts relating to humans can be boring or unnecessary. -Though I don't I have an issue with it, some may find it too action packed and may find it hard to tell what's going on.

The acting starts out decent by Shia LaBeouf but as things progress he gets good. He has a lot of charm and energy that works over time. The supporting cast is good overall with the voice acting by Peter Cullen being incredible. Megan Fox gets better as things go throughout as she gets more character thankfully. Anthony Anderson is very good also. John Turturro feels out of place in this and is the only subpar character. The cinematography is very well done with the special effects being phenomenal on the autobots and decepticons. It isn't a overstatement to say these are some of the most groundbreaking and high quality effects post 2000 that are as good LOTR, Iron Man 1 and The Nolan Dark Knight movies. The action is over the top but really cool and a bit brainless at times. But the effects are so jaw dropping you don't mind the lack of substance. Also there is tons of product placement in this along with classic Michael Bay tropes. (Borderline Softcore Porn shots, oversaturation of explosions/destruction, juvenile humor) The camerawork is solid though with well framed shots and the color saturation helps make the effects blend in also. The music is solid but a bit on the generic side, though its used in the right places well to enhance the action. The editing is good but struggles at first to make the Military Soldiers stories, Sam's story and the U.S. Govt feel like a unified story and jumps around a lot setting it up at first but once the Transformers appear it really comes together well. The pacing is very well done also with the only complaint sometimes the action goes on a bit too long like the final fight which is very well done but runs a bit too long to show off the effects and explosions. This does a great job making you believe a farfetched story. You can feel there is a love behind the source material and the care telling it. Anyone who is a fan of the show, any actors in this, watched this in 2007 as a 15 year old boy and wants to relive their childhood, or Michael Bay will like this.

Transformers (2007) An Underappreciated Masterpiece There are many debates in the modern age surrounding which film franchises have the best visual effects and CGI. Too often the debate centers around Marvel and DC, with some Star Wars and Avatar mixed in. Too little does the incredible film Transformers come into the equation. While some people say that the plot of the first movie in this now 7 film collection is bland, I personally think it is an interesting take on the classic franchise from the 80s. It takes a governmental conspiracy route, taking the main character Sam Witwicky on an unsuspecting journey into an intergalactic war between alien races with some governmental cover ups thrown in. The casting for this movie was an excellent choice, and while the lead roles of Shia LeBouf and Megan Fox certainly don't look 17 as they are supposed to (they were 20 and 21 at the time), they do an excellent job of portraying the socially awkward high school boy, and the popular attractive girl that they represent. The voice acting of Peter Cullen as Optimus Prime is frankly incredible, and he has created an instantly recognizable voice. The soundtrack for this movie is also amazing. Composed by Steve Jablonky, the main title theme and the popular theme "Arrival to Earth" are both beautiful and instantly recognizable among audiences, having created an iconic sound for the movie. The soundtrack for the movie also features songs like "What I've Done" by Linkin Park, creating a wonderful background track for audiences to appreciate. Even if you are someone who agrees that the plot for Transformers (2007) is shallow, it is impossible to deny that the action sequences are some of the best ever portrayed in cinema. Director Michael Bay is a master of intense and engaging visuals, and in Transformers, the large budget allowed him and his team to go above and beyond. The choreography of the fight scenes, coupled with the impressive visual and practical effects, make for incredibly realistic yet intense fight scenes between the characters, leading to a massively engaging watch experience. The visual effects themselves are outright marvelous. Each transformer has hundreds of moving parts that had to be animated and rendered to achieve a cohesive transformation and interaction with the environment. The fact that this movie came out in 2007, yet has robots that look completely real staggers me. While watching Transformers for the first time in 5 years last week, I was expecting to see a couple of uncanny scenes, or scenes where the robots seem out of place, especially since that has become the modern standard with movies such as recent marvel movies. But no. While watching, there was not a single scene that seemed unnatural. Every scene of this now 15 year old movie looks like real life, and for that I have to wonder: Why does barely anyone consider Transformers to be one of the greatest visual effects achievements in cinema history?

Na parte dos humanos, os personagens são interessantes, um destaque para Sam, Mikaela e Lenox que são personagens carismáticos. Infelizmente a que mais sofre com isso é Mikaela que aqui é reduzida a personagem bonita e só. Mas claro que o que realmente interessa nesse filme são os Robôs, e aqui são o ponto mais alto do filme. As a kid I didn't know that Transformers is a set of toys. I only used to think that it is an anime series. The first time I learnt about the movies was when one of my friends got a Nexus tablet to school and played this movie when there was no teacher in the class. I really liked the opening scenes and decided that at some point I will watch this movie. Little did I know that the opportunity will come 8 years later when the lockdown would happen. I watched it and enjoyed it very much. Transformers is exactly what I wanted to watch when I used to see the terrible anime. I didn't like Optimus Prime very much back then but in this movie I understood why he is so important to the franchise and now I am a huge fan of Optimus Prime. There were so many other Transformers whose names I got to learn as I watched this full staff I used to see this movie in parts on TV and I used to think that Bumblebee was Hotshot. After watching this movie I was feeling like replacing the the logo of my car with the Transformers logo. All the Transformers movies have very good CGI, cinematography, choreography and colour grading. What the other movies lack in, however, is a good story and acting. This movie has all of that. I really wish all the other Transformers movies were also like this. Here I cared about Sam, the army guys and of course, Mikaela (°"U"°). This is one of the only two Transformers movies which actually has a good plot (the other doing bumblebee). If the future Transformers movies had built up on what this movie created they could have actually been very awesome. But instead they focused more on creating a bigger universe with more cars and more merch to sell rather than on character development. I can often come back to watch this movie because of the cool cars and fight scenes, without having any of the cringe the future movies had.

This film is a true gem that is sometimes neglected owing to its numerous sequels. Unlike the following several, this one has legendary humor. The photography is superb and the film appears to be really stylish. The narrative revolves on a teenage boy and his car works surprisingly well and feels like many of the more classic Steven Spielberg films such as Jurassic Park or E.T. The dialogue is really good and Glen is very relatable. I think that the way they portray the Decepticons in this movie as absolute hulking unstoppable beasts that you need to work together to defeat was really cool. Several thousand years ago, the planet Cybertron was consumed by a civil war between the two Transformer factions, the Autobots led by Optimus Prime and the Decepticons led by Megatron. Optimus jettisoned the Allspark, a mystical artifact that brings life to the planet and non-biological forms, into space, but Megatron pursued it in spaceship form. Megatron crashed onto Earth, landing in the Arctic Circle and froze, and was discovered in 1895 by explorer Captain Archibald Witwicky. Witwicky inadvertently activated Megatron's navigational system, which etched the Allspark's coordinates into his glasses. The glasses eventually end up in the possession of his great-great-grandson Sam Witwicky (Shia LaBeouf). In the present, a Decepticon named Blackout attacks and destroys a United States military base in Qatar in a failed attempt to hack the military network to find information on Project Iceman (a classified project linked to Megatron's whereabouts) and the AllSpark. A surviving team of Army Rangers led by Captain William Lennox (Josh Duhamel) escape across the desert, pursued by Blackout's drone Scorponok. They fight Scorponok off, aided by aerial reinforcements, and travel home with Scorponok's stinger, discovering sabot rounds damaged its armor. At the Pentagon, Secretary of Defense John Keller leads the investigation into the attack. Data analyst Maggie Madsen catches another Decepticon, Frenzy, hacking into the military network while onboard Air Force One. While the hack is thwarted, Frenzy downloads files on Archibald's glasses, tracking down Sam with Barricade, disguised as a Saleen S281 police car. Maggie makes a copy of the audio signal made during the hacking attempt and goes to her hacker friend Glen Whitmann to decode the signal, but they are promptly arrested by the FBI for having classified information. Meanwhile, Sam buys his first car, a rusting 1976 Chevrolet Camaro, but discovers it has a life of its own. Sam and his high school crush Mikaela Banes (Megan Fox) are rescued from Barricade and Frenzy by the Camaro, who turns out to be the Autobot scout Bumblebee, who has to communicate through his car radio due to being mute. Bumblebee later scans a 2006 Camaro and transforms into a duplicate of it. Bumblebee takes Sam and Mikaela to meet Optimus Prime, Jazz, Ironhide, and Ratchet. Optimus explains that if Megatron gains the AllSpark, he will transform Earth's machinery into a new army and exterminate mankind. Sam, Mikaela, and the Autobots travel to Sam's house to retrieve the glasses, but they are captured by agents of Sector Seven, a top-secret paramilitary government branch which was founded by seven people, led by Agent Seymour Simmons. The Autobots stop the agents but they call for backup, who take Sam, Mikaela, and Bumblebee into custody, though Optimus obtains the glasses and uses them to locate the Allspark... Rotten Tomatoes critical consensus reads, "While believable characters are hard to come by in Transformers, the effects are staggering and the action is exhilarating." IGN's Todd Gilchrist called it Bay's best film, and "one of the few instances where it's OK to enjoy something for being smart and dumb at the same time, mostly because it's undeniably also a whole lot of fun". The Advertiser's Sean Fewster found the visual effects so seamless that "you may come to believe the studio somehow engineered artificial intelligence". The Denver Post's Lisa Kennedy praised the depiction of the robots as having "a believably rendered scale and intimacy", and ABC presenter Margaret Pomeranz was surprised "that a complete newcomer to the Transformers phenomenon like myself became involved in the fate of these mega-machines". Ain't It Cool News's Drew McWeeny felt most of the cast grounded the story, and that "it has a real sense of wonder, one of the things that's missing from so much of the big CGI light shows released these days". Author Peter David found it ludicrous fun, and said that "[Bay] manages to hold on to his audience's suspension of disbelief long enough for us to segue into some truly spectacular battle scenes". Roger Ebert gave the film a positive review, giving it 3 stars out of a possible 4, writing: "It's goofy fun with a lot of stuff that blows up real good, and it has the grace not only to realize how preposterous it is, but to make that into an asset." Despite the praise for the visual effects, there was division over the human storylines. The Hollywood Reporter's Kirk Honeycutt liked "how a teen plotline gets tied in to the end of the world", while Empire's Ian Nathan praised Shia LaBeouf as "a smart, natural comedian, [who] levels the bluntness of this toy story with an ironic bluster". Ain't It Cool News founder Harry Knowles felt Bay's style conflicted with Spielberg's, arguing the military story only served as a distraction from Sam. James Berardinelli hated the film as he did not connect with the characters in-between the action, which he found tedious. Los Angeles Times' Kenneth Turan found the humans "oddly lifeless, doing little besides marking time until those big toys fill the screen", while ComingSoon.net's Joshua Starnes felt the Transformers were "completely believable, right up to the moment they open their mouths to talk, when they revert to bad cartoon characters". Daily Herald's Matt Arado was annoyed that "the Transformers [are] little more than supporting players", and felt the middle act was sluggish. CNN's Tom Charity questioned the idea of a film based on a toy, and felt it would "buzz its youthful demographic [...] but leave the rest of us wondering if Hollywood could possibly aim lower". "Transformers" received mixed reviews from critics and audiences. It became the 28th highest-grossing film of all-time at the time of its release and was the fifth highest-grossing film of 2007, grossing $709 million worldwide, with an estimated 46 million tickets sold in the US. The film won four awards from the Visual Effects Society and was nominated for three Academy Awards, for Best Sound Editing, Best Sound Mixing, and Best Visual Effects. LaBeouf's performance was praised by Empire, and Cullen's reprisal of Optimus Prime from the 1980s television series was well received by fans. The film was followed by four sequels, Revenge of the Fallen (2009), Dark of the Moon (2011), Age of Extinction (2014), and The Last Knight (2017), as well as a spin-off titled Bumblebee in 2018. "Transformers" is a bit silly and a too loud Michael Bay production based on the classic Transformers toys from Hasbro. It´s a lot of bang for the bucks, but this is not my type of film.

Transformers is a style over substance movie, although calling it a bad film may be a stretch. From a writing standpoint, it offers barley anything meaningful or even that interesting. The story is clunky, overstuffed, and all over the place. The initial plot of a teenager finding a car that turns into a robot that is engaged in a war with other robots is already enough. But there are also other subplots, like the cliché romantic subplot, and another subplot with these (hackers?). The characters are also very uninteresting. All of them are one-dimensional and nothing about them stands out all that much. The acting is mostly hit & miss. For example, Shia LaBeouf does a good job, however Megan Fox doesn't. This is a film that is purely saved by its effects. While the visuals are far from perfect, with some annoying shaky cam and a bland look, the effects themselves, both CG and practical, are really good, and seriously impressive for 2007. The same can be said for the sound design, immersing the audience into the film even more. Both those things combined give some flawed but fun action scenes. Transformers is fun. If your in the mood to watch some mindless action, then this isn't the worse choice.

Probably the first time I saw this film I had no idea what it meant and just looked impressed while looking at the CGI characters while looking for a logical background for the explosive, destructive and very conspicuous action scenes, which sway from a cut there, a cut here. Nowadays with a lot more sense of things and a high critical sense for films, I can see that the first installment of this future blockbuster franchise is not as bad as everything else, here we see a beautiful parallel for the arrival of robots on earth accompanied by the vision of a teenager who, however dull he may seem at first, still manages to be pleasant and taken seriously when he needs to. The film besides the incredible special effects that will always be a subject to come up when talking about this franchise in general, the film still manages to bring some good moments of humor, however much the action scenes may leave a little to be desired when comes to boredom, they are still exciting and offer good fun. That is, as far as it is far from perfect, at least it is assistable and fun at times, unlike other films.
Rewatching this at home, I always have a blast and never understood the hate that it got. Except for from long time Transformers fans. But still an instant classic!

Transformers is overall a well done and fun film. The main reason I like this movie and other like this movie, is because of the action. The action is so exhilerating. One problem that people find with the movie is that the action is over the top, even though that is what makes the movie entertaining. Apparently, people say that the characters are uncompelling. It is not like the characters are compelling or uncompelling. They are just characters. They do not hurt or help the movie as a whole. The movie is not for the whole family. Anyone who is a kid, tween, or younger teen will enjoy it. There really is not much to say about the movie except great action, outstanding special effects, and an overall fun movie.

The human characters are all generally a bit cheesy, and several are particularly poorly thought out and written. The characters of the Transformers themselves can also be a bit lacking and not particularly well-developed, but I'm not sure all of that matters. This is the ORIGINAL Transformers movie, and perhaps now we take the big explosions and overblown action for granted, seeing as a long line of inferior sequels have been churned out, but this was still the first, and it is by far the best. No matter how poor the writing is, the visuals are truly masterful, and the action/special effects will still take your breath away. By no means is this film the Citizen Kane of our generation, but it will be remembered for its' technical innovation, and I would still recommend it despite all of the negatives.

Before the Transformers franchise became a punchline, i can recall audiences loving the first installment with over-exuberance. I can't say that i was one of them. This was an obnoxiously loud, over-the-top extravaganza from none other than Michael Bay. Of course, you get all the typical Michael Bay signatures; plenty of explosions, a number of slow-mo shots, a sexy female actress, and a palette of sharp colors. Not to mention, there was an over indulgence of CGI action to overload one's senses into hyperdrive. It tries to do way more than the standard action thriller, but ends up containing too many empty calories with zero nutritional value.

Despite being predictable in the script, it's still a fun film to watch. But, the downside is this. Shia Labeouf is really annoying as an insecure high schooler. I'm going to be honest. I was like that too, but I wasn't as big of an idiot as LeBeouf.
